arm_group.arm_group_label: study 1: aqueous cream and baby oil
arm_group.description: enrolled patients in this arm use either aqueous cream or baby oil as a soap substitute
patients in this study arm continue to use emulsifying ointment and cetomacrogol as a moisturiser, the current standard of care in our institution

brief_summary.textblock:
Aqueous (EUA) cream, cetomacrogol (CMG) and emulsifying ointment (HEB) are in South Africa's
      essential drug list (EDL) but are not available to most rural patients. To assess whether
      accessible moisturizers can be used as alternatives in atopic eczema (AD), a randomized
      controlled trial of patients with mild-to-moderate AD, aged 1-12 years was conducted. Two
      separate sub-studies were conducted using a randomized controlled single (assessor) blind
      trial design. Study 1 compared UEA vs. liquid paraffin (unscented baby oil) for baths, all
      patients used HEB as moisturiser. In Study 2,  4 moisturisers were compared -HEB, CMG,
      petroleum jelly and petroleum jelly/Glycerine (2:1). Assessments (SCORAD, POEM, NESS and
      IQDOL) carried out at baseline, week 4, 8 and 12. Routine topical steroids and
      antihistamines were continued as prescribed.

clinical_study.brief_title: Accessible and Affordable Moisturizers for Atopic Eczema

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:

          -  Patients with Atopic dermatitis as defined by the united kingdom (UK) Working party
             Diagnostic Criteria

          -  Atopic Dermatitis patient with mild to moderate stable atopic eczema with
             parents/guardians willing and able to apply study moisturizers as directed and commit
             to attend all visits.

        Exclusion Criteria:

          -  Less than 1 year of age

          -  Patients with atopic dermatitis treated with systemic preparations

intervention.arm_group_label: study 1: aqueous cream and baby oil
intervention.description: patient in study 1, arm B washed unscented liquid paraffin (baby oil) in place of aqueous cream
patients in this arm, use petroleum jelly (vaseline), replacing emulsifying ointment as a moisturiser
patients in this arm use glycerine and petroleum jelly mixed at a ratio of 2:1 in place of cetomacrogol as a moisturiser

facility.name: Red Cross War Memorial Children's Hospital

clinical_study.official_title: Accessible and Affordable Moisturizers for Atopic Eczema: the 2am Atopic Eczema Study

overall_official.affiliation: Red Cross War Memorial Children's Hospital

primary_outcome.description: Change in the validated SCORing Atopic Dermatitis(SCORAD) and two other validated clinical scores (Nottingham Atopic Eczema Severity Score(NESS) and Patient Oriented Eczema Measure(POEM) were used to measure the extent/severity of AD. A validated quality-of-life form using the infants dermatitis quality of life (IDQOL) scale was completed by each care-giver at each visit.
primary_outcome.measure: Change in the validated SCORing Atopic Dermatitis(SCORAD)

required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on June 04, 2014
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

responsible_party.investigator_affiliation: Red Cross War Memorial Childrens Hospital

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in the patient quality-of-life as measured by the infants dermatitis quality of life (IDQOL) index at each visit.

clinical_study.source: Red Cross War Memorial Childrens Hospital

lead_sponsor.agency: Red Cross War Memorial Childrens Hospital

clinical_study.study_design: Allocation: Randomized, Endpoint Classification: Bio-equivalence Study, Intervention Model: Parallel Assignment, Masking: Single Blind (Investigator)
